CHAPTER SIX
PTOLEMY
1. FROM THE GREEK INTO ARABIC AND
FROM ARABIC INTO LATIN
The Optics of Ptolemy was first published in Latin by Gilberto
Govi in 1885, but it remained unknown to historians of art
and perspective until 1957, when Decio Gioseffi mentioned it
for the first time. However, this scholar limited his analysis to
just a few lines of paragraph 4 of book III, a paragraph that will
also be analyzed in this chapter. From that point on, Ptolemy's
Optics has not, as far as I know, been taken into consideration
by historians of art and perspective.
The principal reason that scholars have abstained from
studying Ptolemy's Optics is especially because of the diffi-
culty of the Latin language in which the work has come down
to us. The admiral Eugenius of Sicily, who lived in the second
half of the twelfth century at the court of the Norman kings in
Palermo, translated Ptolemy's Optics from Arabic into Latin; the
Arabic version was, in its turn, a translation from the Greek, the
language in which Ptolemy, living in the first half of the second
century A.D., had written the work. Govi was the first to rightly
underscore that the Latin is quite often obscure because it was a
literal translation from Arabic and that the geometric concepts

are often improper as a result of the translator's ignorance of
the correct expressions needed to be able to translate them from
Arabic into Latin. There is no known documentation regarding
the existence of the Arabic text from which the Latin is derived,
nor is there any information regarding the original Greek text
from which the Arabic is derived.
These same difficulties of interpretation were expressed by
Albert Lejeune, who spoke of a translation of a translation,
such that it could discourage any reader in good faith, and by
A. Mark Smith, who spoke of a text difficult to penetrate, being
so tortuous and confused that it is often incomprehensible.³
Again, it is worth noting that both Lejeune and Smith, in
providing their first translations in French and in English, took
upon themselves an onerous task, not unlike that of paleogra-
phers, when these scholars attempt to decipher deep layers of
a palimpsest. For this reason, Lejeune and Smith were forced
to adhere scrupulously to an exegetic reconstruction of a very
difficult text.
My task, however, has been first of all to take a look at the
entire reconstructed work of the Ptolemaic text by Lejeune
and Smith, then successively to go beyond it in an attempt to
specifically illustrate some passages of the Optics with draw-
ings, and finally to compare them in modern terms with the
geometric theories of representation."
Let us begin with Sermo Tertius De Opticis Tholomei, that is to
say "The Third Speech on the Optics of Ptolemy" - also known
as "The Third Book (or Sermon)" on the Optics, according to
how we prefer to translate the Latin word Sermo-naturally
limiting our attention to an analysis of flat mirrors only.

In this paragraph two invitations can be found. The first
consists of marking - or, better yet, tracing - the points that
appear on the mirror and then opportunely interweaving them.

from the mirror.

In this paragraph, it is specified that the disposition of the
eyes is constituted as if the one sees the other in the same instant
on a single and same point between the two that one sees on the
mirror. If this were not so, the eyes would operate separately,
each for itself in such a way as to have a double reflection: one
for each eye. Thus it is clear that the double reflection did not
exist for the ancients, as it does not exist for us, because this
entailed, then as now, the visual alteration to which has been
given the name dyplopia.
Therefore, the fundamental notion that is at the base of
vision remains certified: the cyclopic unity of sight, with the
consequent coincidence of the two optical axes in one princi-
pal visual axis. This unity, scientifically linked to the loss, in
the reflection of the mirrors, of one of the two optical axes,15
becomes the conditio sine qua non, placed at the base of the the-
ory of vision, and allows us to mark a single eye O, or one sole
pupil, instead of two (Fig. 89).
Let us now analyze the motivations that justify the presence
of the points O' and O" that we have marked and what are the
effective meanings that Ptolemy gives them.

8. THE POSITION OF THE VIRTUAL APPARENT FORM
Let us continue to focus our attention on the meaning of the
"associated" image, in which coincide the reflected image and
the straightforward image of the virtual object. One may draw
three principal fundamentals from this paragraph:
1. The images of straight lines, or portions of the same lines,
erected upon the flat mirrors, are seen according to straight
lines without bending (videntur secundum rectitudinem sine
proclivitate): this important factor implies that these images
are not curved or arched (Fig. 91).
2. The images of straight lines, or portions of the same lines,
erected upon flat mirrors, "appear positioned on the same
side toward which the objects move" (apparent translate
ad eandem partem ad quam res moventur); that is why, for
example, if one has the sequence 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, et cetera,
which begins to part from the mirror, this sequence will
have to part in this same exact order also from the opposite
side beyond the mirror.
3. Through the order of the rectilinear sequence, one can find
the position of the apparent "not true" object, that is to
say, the "virtual" object (ita procedimus et in cognitione loci
forme non vere apparentis).
Let us explain by means of examples what this implies. If we
have a drawing, represented by simple lines and simple points,
one can immediately draw its reverse, or vice versa, if we have
its reverse, one can immediately draw its obverse with the cor-
respondence now described: this is the simple law of symme-
try. Applying this concept, for example, the real points Tc, A,
B, et cetera, on one side, will be set on the opposite side always
in the order Tc, A", B", starting from the mirror (Fig. 92) - a
phenomenon that generates the turning over of the sequence
and therefore the reversal of the square, with the inversion of
the respective arrows.

To show the forms, or rather the images of the things that

15. THE THREE PROJECTIONS OF THE
SPHERE PRESENT IN PTOLEMY
Through the theory of mirrors, Ptolemy reduced the three-
dimensional reality of objects to a plane, but beyond this he
also treated the projection onto a plane of the celestial vault
and the terrestrial sphere. In fact, he constructed celestial and
terrestrial maps based on very precise geometrical principles.
The sphere, which is impossible to develop on a plane, is also
particularly difficult to represent. Ptolemy found the images
through exact projections, using a center and a projection
plane those very elements which we have studied in the the-
ory of mirrors.
First of all, he fixed the essential elements of reference
for the terrestrial sphere the axis, the poles, the equator,
the parallels, and the meridians. And, consequently, for the
celestial sphere, which is considered an immense enlarge-
ment of the terrestrial sphere, he established the celestial
meridians, the celestial equator, the ecliptic, the equinoc-
tial colure, and the astronomical horizon all elements that
serve to establish both geographical and astronomical point
coordinates.
